#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=CHAPTER XI .
#Text=FAITH AND UNFAITH
#Text=At Jane Withersteen 's home
#Text=the promise made to Mrs. Larkin to care for little Fay had begun to be fulfilled .
#Text=Like a gleam of sunlight through the cottonwoods was the coming of the child to the gloomy house of Withersteen .
#Text=The big , silent halls echoed with childish laughter .
#Text=In the shady court , where Jane spent many of the hot July days , Fay 's tiny feet pattered over the stone flags and splashed in the amber stream .
#Text=She prattled incessantly .
#Text=What difference , Jane thought , a child made in her home !
#Text=It had never been a real home , she discovered .
#Text=Even the tidiness and neatness she had so observed , and upon which she had insisted to her women , became , in the light of Fay 's smile , habits that now lost their importance .
#Text=Fay littered the court with Jane 's books and papers , and other toys her fancy improvised , and many a strange craft went floating down the little brook .
#Text=And it was owing to Fay 's presence that Jane Withersteen came to see more of Lassiter .
#Text=The rider had for the most part kept to the sage .
#Text=He rode for her , but he did not seek her except on business ; and Jane had to acknowledge in pique that her overtures had been made in vain .
#Text=Fay , however , captured Lassiter the moment he first laid eyes on her .
#Text=Jane was present at the meeting , and there was something about it which dimmed her sight and softened her toward this foe of her people .

#Text=The rider had clanked into the court , a tired yet wary man , always looking for the attack upon him that was inevitable and might come from any quarter ; and he had walked right upon little Fay .

#Text=The child had been beautiful even in her rags and amid the surroundings of the hovel in the sage , but now , in a pretty white dress , with her shining curls brushed and her face clean and rosy , she was lovely .
#Text=She left her play and looked up at Lassiter .
#Text=If there was not an instinct for all three of them in that meeting , an unreasoning tendency toward a closer intimacy , then Jane Withersteen believed she had been subject to a queer fancy .
#Text=She imagined any child would have feared Lassiter .
#Text=And Fay Larkin had been a lonely , a solitary elf of the sage , not at all an ordinary child , and exquisitely shy with strangers .
#Text=She watched Lassiter with great , round , grave eyes , but showed no fear .
#Text=The rider gave Jane a favorable report of cattle and horses ; and as he took the seat to which she invited him , little Fay edged as much as half an inch nearer .
#Text=Jane replied to his look of inquiry and told Fay 's story .
#Text=The rider 's gray , earnest gaze troubled her .
#Text=Then he turned to Fay and smiled in a way that made Jane doubt her sense of the true relation of things .
#Text=How could Lassiter smile so at a child when he had made so many children fatherless ?
#Text=But he did smile , and to the gentleness she had seen a few times he added something that was infinitely sad and sweet .
#Text=Jane 's intuition told her that Lassiter had never been a father , but if life ever so blessed him he would be a good one .
#Text=Fay , also , must have found that smile singularly winning .
#Text=For she edged closer and closer , and then , by way of feminine capitulation , went to Jane , from whose side she bent a beautiful glance upon the rider .
#Text=Lassiter only smiled at her .
#Text=Jane watched them , and realized that now was the moment she should seize , if she was ever to win this man from his hatred .
#Text=But the step was not easy to take .
#Text=The more she saw of Lassiter the more she respected him , and the greater her respect the harder it became to lend herself to mere coquetry .

#Text=Yet as she thought of her great motive , of Tull , and of that other whose name she had schooled herself never to think of in connection with Milly Erne 's avenger , she suddenly found she had no choice .
#Text=And her creed gave her boldness far beyond the limit to which vanity would have led her .
#Text=“ Lassiter , I see so little of you now , ” she said , and was conscious of heat in her cheeks .
#Text=“ I 've been riding hard , ” he replied .
#Text=“ But you ca n't live in the saddle .
#Text=You come in sometimes .
#Text=Wo n't you come here to see me -- oftener ? ”
#Text=“ Is that an order ? ”
#Text=“ Nonsense !
#Text=I simply ask you to come to see me when you find time . ”
#Text=“ Why ? ”
#Text=The query once heard was not so embarrassing to Jane as she might have imagined .
#Text=Moreover , it established in her mind a fact that there existed actually other than selfish reasons for her wanting to see him .
#Text=And as she had been bold , so she determined to be both honest and brave .
#Text=“ I 've reasons -- only one of which I need mention , ” she answered .
#Text=“ If it 's possible I want to change you toward my people .
#Text=And on the moment I can conceive of little I would n't do to gain that end . ”
#Text=How much better and freer Jane felt after that confession !
#Text=She meant to show him that there was one Mormon who could play a game or wage a fight in the open .
